column1: And here's a rose   To make it right again!
column2: God knows   I'm sorry, Grace; but then, It's not my fault if you will be a cat.
column3: An After Song     So art thou broken in upon me, Apollo,     Through a splendour of purple garments--   Held by the yellow-haired Clymene   To clothe the white of thy shoulders--   Bare from the day's leaping of horses.
column4: This is strange to me, here in the modern twilight.
column5: Crude Lament Mother of flames,   The men that went ahunting Are asleep in the snow drifts.
column6: You have kept the fire burning!
column7: Crooked fingers that pull Fuel from among the wet leaves,   Mother of flames   You have kept the fire burning!
column8: The young wives have fallen asleep With wet hair, weeping,   Mother of flames!
column9: The young men raised the heavy spears And are gone prowling in the darkness.
column10: O mother of flames,   You who have kept the fire burning!
column12: Would God they had taken me with them!
column13: The Ordeal O Crimson salamander,   Because of love's whim                     sacred!
column14: Swim   the winding flame   Predestined to disman him And bring our fellow home to us again.
column15: Swim in with watery fang,   Gnaw out and drown The fire roots that circle him Until the Hell-flower dies down   And he comes home again.
column16: Aye, bring him home,   O crimson salamander, That I may see he is unchanged with burning-- Then have your will with him,   O crimson salamander.
column17: The Death of Franco of Cologne: His Prophecy of Beethoven It is useless, good woman, useless: the spark fails me.
column19: yet when the might of it all assails me It seems impossible that I cannot do it.
column21: They were right, and they all knew it Years ago, but I--never!
column22: I have persisted Blindly (they say) and now I am old.
column23: I have resisted Everything, but now, now the strife's ended.
column24: The fire's out; the old cloak has been mended For the last time, the soul peers through its tatters.
column25: Put a light by and leave me; nothing more matters Now; I am done; I am at last well broken!
column26: Yet, by God, I'll still leave them a token That they'll swear it was no dead man writ it; A morsel that they'll mark well the day they bit it, That there'll be sand between their gross teeth to crunch yet When goodman Gabriel blows his concluding trumpet.
column28: And now, little black eyes, come you out here!
column29: Ah, you've given me a lively, lasting bout, year After year to win you round me darlings!
column31: "farlings" They might have called you once, "nearlings" I call you now, I, first of all the yearlings, Upon this plain, for I it was that tore you Out of chaos!
column33: Ah, you little children that go playing Over the five-barred gate, and will still be straying Spite of all that I have ever told you Of counterpoint and cadence which does not hold you-- No more than chains will for this or that strange reason, But you're always at some new loving treason To be away from me, laughing, mocking, Witlessly, perhaps, but for all that forever knocking At this stanchion door of your poor father's heart till--oh, well At least you've shown that you can grow well However much you evade me faster, faster.
column34: But, black eyes, some day you'll get a master, For he will come!
column36: And when he finishes and the burning dust from His wheels settles--what shall men see then?
column37: You, you, you, my own lovely children!
column38: Aye, all of you, thus with hands together Playing on the hill or there in a tether, Or running free, but all mine!
column39: Aye, my very namesakes Shall be his proper fame's stakes.
column42: And he shall build you gold palaces!
column43: And he shall wine you from clear chalices!
column45: I have seen it Written where the world-clouds screen it From other eyes Over the bronze gates of paradise!
column46: Portent Red cradle of the night,   In you       The dusky child Sleeps fast till his might   Shall be piled Sinew on sinew.
column47: Red cradle of the night,   The dusky child Sleeping sits upright.
column48: Lo how           The winds blow now!
column49: He pillows back; The winds are again mild.
column50: When he stretches his arms out, Red cradle of the night,   The alarms shout From bare tree to tree,   Wild         In afright!
column51: Mighty shall he be, Red cradle of the night,   The dusky child!!
column52: Con Brio Miserly, is the best description of that poor fool Who holds Lancelot to have been a morose fellow, Dolefully brooding over the events which had naturally to follow The high time of his deed with Guinevere.
column53: He has a sick historical sight, if I judge rightly, To believe any such thing as that ever occurred.
column54: But, by the god of blood, what else is it that has deterred Us all from an out and out defiance of fear But this same perdamnable miserliness, Which cries about our necks how we shall have less and less Than we have now if we spend too wantonly?
column55: Bah, this sort of slither is below contempt!
column56: In the same vein we should have apple trees exempt From bearing anything but pink blossoms all the year, Fixed permanent lest their bellies wax unseemly, and the dear Innocent days of them be wasted quite.
column59: Lancelot thought little, spent his gold and rode to fight Mounted, if God was willing, on a good steed.
column60: Ad Infinitum   Still I bring flowers Although you fling them at my feet   Until none stays That is not struck across with wounds:   Flowers and flowers That you may break them utterly   As you have always done.
column61: Sure happily I still bring flowers, flowers,   Knowing how all Are crumpled in your praise   And may not live To speak a lesser thing.
column62: Translations from the Spanish, "El Romancero"               I   Although you do your best to regard me   With an air seeming offended,   Never can you deny, when all's ended,   Calm eyes, that you _did_ regard me.
column63: However much you're at pains to Offend me, by which I may suffer, What offence is there can make up for The great good he finds who attains you?
column64: For though with mortal fear you reward me, Until my sorry sense is plenished, Never can you deny, when all's ended, Calm eyes, that you did regard me.
column65: Thinking thus to dismay me You beheld me with disdain, But instead of destroying the gain, In fact with doubled good you paid me.
column66: For though you show them how hardly They keep off from leniency bended, Never can you deny, when all's ended, Calm eyes, that you did regard me.
column67: II Ah, little green eyes, Ah, little eyes of mine, Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me somewise.
column68: The day of departure You came full of grieving And to see I was leaving The tears 'gan to start sure With the heavy torture Of sorrows unbrightened When you lie down at night and When there to you dreams rise, Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me somewise.
column69: Deep is my assurance Of you, little green eyes, That in truth you realise Something of my durance Eyes of hope's fair assurance And good premonition By virtue of whose condition All green colours I prize.
column70: Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me somewise.
column71: Would God I might know you To which quarter bended And why comprehended When sighings overflow you, And if you must go through Some certain despair, For that you lose his care Who was faithful always.
column72: Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me these days.
column73: Through never a moment I've known how to live lest All my thoughts but as one pressed You-ward for their concernment.
column74: May God send chastisement If in this I belie me And if it truth be My own little green eyes.
column75: Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me somewise.
column76: III Poplars of the meadow, Fountains of Madrid, Now I am absent from you All are slandering me.
column77: Each of you is telling How evil my chance is The wind among the branches, The fountains in their welling To every one telling You were happy to see.
column78: Now I am absent from you All are slandering me.
column79: With good right I may wonder For that at my last leaving The plants with sighs heaving And the waters in tears were.
column80: That you played double, never Thought I this could be, Now I am absent from you All are slandering me.
column81: There full in your presence Music you sought to waken, Later I'm forsaken Since you are ware of my absence.
column82: God, wilt Thou give me patience Here while suffer I ye, Now I am absent from you All are slandering me.
column83: IV The day draweth nearer, And morrow ends our meeting, Ere they take thee sleeping Be up--away, my treasure!
column84: Soft, leave her breasts all unheeded, Far hence though the master still remaineth!
column85: For soon uptil our earth regaineth The sun all embraces dividing.
column86: N'er grew pleasure all unimpeded, N'er was delight lest passion won, And to the wise man the fit occasion Has not yet refused a full measure: Be up--away, my treasure!
column87: If that my love thy bosom inflameth With honest purpose and just intention, To free me from my soul's contention Give over joys the day shameth; Who thee lameth he also me lameth, And my good grace builds all in thy good grace; Be up--away!
column88: Fear leaveth place, That thou art here, no more unto pleasure, Be up--away, my treasure!
column89: Although thou with a sleep art wresting, 'Tis rightful thou bringst it close, That of the favour one meeting shows An hundred may hence be attesting.
column90: 'Tis fitting too thou shouldst be mindful That the ease which we lose now, in kind, full Many a promise holds for our leisure; Ere they take thee sleeping; Be up--away, my treasure!
column91: Hic Jacet The coroner's merry little children   Have such twinkling brown eyes.
column92: Their father is not of gay men   And their mother jocular in no wise, Yet the coroner's merry little children         Laugh so easily.
column94: Fruit for them is upon all branches.
column96: how they jibe at loss, for   Kind heaven fills their little paunches!
column97: It's the coroner's merry, merry children         Who laugh so easily.
column98: Contemporania The corner of a great rain Steamy with the country Has fallen upon my garden.
column99: I go back and forth now And the little leaves follow me Talking of the great rain, Of branches broken, And the farmer's curses!
column100: But I go back and forth In this corner of a garden And the green shoots follow me Praising the great rain.
column101: We are not curst together, The leaves and I, Framing devices, flower devices And other ways of peopling The barren country.
column102: Truly it was a very great rain That makes the little leaves follow me.
column103: To wish Myself Courage On the day when youth is no more upon me I will write of the leaves and the moon in a tree top!
column104: I will sing then the song, long in the making-- When the stress of youth is put away from me.
column105: How can I ever be written out as men say?
column106: Surely it is merely an interference with the long song-- This that I am now doing.
column107: But when the spring of it is worn like the old moon And the eaten leaves are lace upon the cold earth-- Then I will rise up in my great desire-- Long at the birth--and sing me the youth-song!

column229: THE TEMPERS THE TEMPERS BY WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS LONDON ELKIN MATHEWS, CORK STREET M CM XIII TO CARLOS HOHEB CONTENTS                                                                  PAGE Peace on Earth                                                      7 Postlude                                                            8 First Praise                                                        9 Homage                                                             10 The Fool's Song                                                    11 From "The Birth of Venus," Song                                    12 Immortal                                                           13 Mezzo Forte                                                        14 An After Song                                                      15 Crude Lament                                                       16 The Ordeal                                                         17 The Death of Franco of Cologne: His Prophecy of Beethoven          18 Portent                                                            21 Con Brio                                                           22 Ad Infinitum                                                       23 Translations from the Spanish, "El Romancero"                      24 Hic Jacet                                                          30 Contemporania                                                      31 To wish Myself Courage                                             32 Peace on Earth The Archer is wake!
column231: Gold against blue An Arrow is lying.
column232: There is hunting in heaven-- Sleep safe till to-morrow.
column235: Gold against blue Their eyes are gleaming!
column238: The Sisters lie With their arms intertwining; Gold against blue Their hair is shining!
column241: Gold against blue His sword is glistening!
column243: There is hunting in heaven-- Sleep safe till to-morrow.
column244: Postlude Now that I have cooled to you Let there be gold of tarnished masonry, Temples soothed by the sun to ruin That sleep utterly.
column245: Give me hand for the dances, Ripples at Philae, in and out, And lips, my Lesbian, Wall flowers that once were flame.
column246: Your hair is my Carthage And my arms the bow, And our words arrows To shoot the stars Who from that misty sea Swarm to destroy us.
column247: But you there beside me-- Oh how shall I defy you, Who wound me in the night With breasts shining Like Venus and like Mars?
column248: The night that is shouting Jason When the loud eaves rattle As with waves above me Blue at the prow of my desire.
column249: First Praise Lady of dusk wood fastnesses,   Thou art my Lady.
column250: I have known the crisp splintering leaf-tread with thee on before, White, slender through green saplings; I have lain by thee on the grey forest floor   Beside thee, my Lady.
column251: Lady of rivers strewn with stones,   Only thou art my Lady.
column252: Where thousand the freshets are crowded like peasants to a fair; Clear skinned, wild from seclusion, They jostle white armed down the tent-bordered thoroughfare   Praising my Lady.
column253: Homage Elvira, by love's grace There goeth before you A clear radiance Which maketh all vain souls Candles when noon is.
column254: The loud clangour of pretenders Melteth before you Like the roll of carts passing, But you come silently And homage is given.
column255: Now the little by-path Which leadeth to love Is again joyful with its many; And the great highway From love Is without passers.
column256: The Fool's Song I tried to put a bird in a cage.
column259: Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put     Truth in a cage!
column260: And when I had the bird in the cage,     O fool that I am!
column261: Why, it broke my pretty cage.
column262: Sing merrily, Truth; I tried to put     Truth in a cage!
column263: And when the bird was flown from the cage,     O fool that I am!
column264: Why, I had nor bird nor cage.
column265: Sing merrily, Truth: I tried to put     Truth in a cage!
column268: From "The Birth of Venus," Song     Come with us and play!
column269: See, we have breasts as women!
column270: From your tents by the sea Come play with us: it is forbidden!
column272: Lo, bare, straight legs in the water!
column273: By our boats we stay,     Then swimming away Come to us: it is forbidden!
column275: See, we are tall as women!
column276: Our eyes are keen:     Our hair is bright: Our voices speak outright: We revel in the sea's green!
column278: Immortal Yes, there is one thing braver than all flowers;     Richer than clear gems; wider than the sky; Immortal and unchangeable; whose powers     Transcend reason, love and sanity!
column279: And thou, beloved, art that godly thing!
column280: Marvellous and terrible; in glance An injured Juno roused against Heaven's King!
column281: And thy name, lovely One, is Ignorance.
column282: Mezzo Forte Take that, damn you; and that!
column283: And here's a rose   To make it right again!
column284: God knows   I'm sorry, Grace; but then, It's not my fault if you will be a cat.
column285: An After Song     So art thou broken in upon me, Apollo,     Through a splendour of purple garments--   Held by the yellow-haired Clymène   To clothe the white of thy shoulders--   Bare from the day's leaping of horses.
column286: This is strange to me, here in the modern twilight.
column287: Crude Lament Mother of flames,   The men that went ahunting Are asleep in the snow drifts.
column288: You have kept the fire burning!
column289: Crooked fingers that pull Fuel from among the wet leaves,   Mother of flames   You have kept the fire burning!
column290: The young wives have fallen asleep With wet hair, weeping,   Mother of flames!
column291: The young men raised the heavy spears And are gone prowling in the darkness.
column292: O mother of flames,   You who have kept the fire burning!
column294: Would God they had taken me with them!
column295: The Ordeal O Crimson salamander,   Because of love's whim                     sacred!
column296: Swim   the winding flame   Predestined to disman him And bring our fellow home to us again.
column297: Swim in with watery fang,   Gnaw out and drown The fire roots that circle him Until the Hell-flower dies down   And he comes home again.
column298: Aye, bring him home,   O crimson salamander, That I may see he is unchanged with burning-- Then have your will with him,   O crimson salamander.
column299: The Death of Franco of Cologne: His Prophecy of Beethoven It is useless, good woman, useless: the spark fails me.
column301: yet when the might of it all assails me It seems impossible that I cannot do it.
column303: They were right, and they all knew it Years ago, but I--never!
column304: I have persisted Blindly (they say) and now I am old.
column305: I have resisted Everything, but now, now the strife's ended.
column306: The fire's out; the old cloak has been mended For the last time, the soul peers through its tatters.
column307: Put a light by and leave me; nothing more matters Now; I am done; I am at last well broken!
column308: Yet, by God, I'll still leave them a token That they'll swear it was no dead man writ it; A morsel that they'll mark well the day they bit it, That there'll be sand between their gross teeth to crunch yet When goodman Gabriel blows his concluding trumpet.
column310: And now, little black eyes, come you out here!
column311: Ah, you've given me a lively, lasting bout, year After year to win you round me darlings!
column313: "farlings" They might have called you once, "nearlings" I call you now, I, first of all the yearlings, Upon this plain, for I it was that tore you Out of chaos!
column315: Ah, you little children that go playing Over the five-barred gate, and will still be straying Spite of all that I have ever told you Of counterpoint and cadence which does not hold you-- No more than chains will for this or that strange reason, But you're always at some new loving treason To be away from me, laughing, mocking, Witlessly, perhaps, but for all that forever knocking At this stanchion door of your poor father's heart till--oh, well At least you've shown that you can grow well However much you evade me faster, faster.
column316: But, black eyes, some day you'll get a master, For he will come!
column318: And when he finishes and the burning dust from His wheels settles--what shall men see then?
column319: You, you, you, my own lovely children!
column320: Aye, all of you, thus with hands together Playing on the hill or there in a tether, Or running free, but all mine!
column321: Aye, my very namesakes Shall be his proper fame's stakes.
column324: And he shall build you gold palaces!
column325: And he shall wine you from clear chalices!
column327: I have seen it Written where the world-clouds screen it From other eyes Over the bronze gates of paradise!
column328: Portent Red cradle of the night,   In you       The dusky child Sleeps fast till his might   Shall be piled Sinew on sinew.
column329: Red cradle of the night,   The dusky child Sleeping sits upright.
column330: Lo how           The winds blow now!
column331: He pillows back; The winds are again mild.
column332: When he stretches his arms out, Red cradle of the night,   The alarms shout From bare tree to tree,   Wild         In afright!
column333: Mighty shall he be, Red cradle of the night,   The dusky child!!
column334: Con Brio Miserly, is the best description of that poor fool Who holds Lancelot to have been a morose fellow, Dolefully brooding over the events which had naturally to follow The high time of his deed with Guinevere.
column335: He has a sick historical sight, if I judge rightly, To believe any such thing as that ever occurred.
column336: But, by the god of blood, what else is it that has deterred Us all from an out and out defiance of fear But this same perdamnable miserliness, Which cries about our necks how we shall have less and less Than we have now if we spend too wantonly?
column337: Bah, this sort of slither is below contempt!
column338: In the same vein we should have apple trees exempt From bearing anything but pink blossoms all the year, Fixed permanent lest their bellies wax unseemly, and the dear Innocent days of them be wasted quite.
column341: Lancelot thought little, spent his gold and rode to fight Mounted, if God was willing, on a good steed.
column342: Ad Infinitum   Still I bring flowers Although you fling them at my feet   Until none stays That is not struck across with wounds:   Flowers and flowers That you may break them utterly   As you have always done.
column343: Sure happily I still bring flowers, flowers,   Knowing how all Are crumpled in your praise   And may not live To speak a lesser thing.
column344: Translations from the Spanish, "El Romancero"               I   Although you do your best to regard me   With an air seeming offended,   Never can you deny, when all's ended,   Calm eyes, that you _did_ regard me.
column345: However much you're at pains to Offend me, by which I may suffer, What offence is there can make up for The great good he finds who attains you?
column346: For though with mortal fear you reward me, Until my sorry sense is plenished, Never can you deny, when all's ended, Calm eyes, that you did regard me.
column347: Thinking thus to dismay me You beheld me with disdain, But instead of destroying the gain, In fact with doubled good you paid me.
column348: For though you show them how hardly They keep off from leniency bended, Never can you deny, when all's ended, Calm eyes, that you did regard me.
column349: II Ah, little green eyes, Ah, little eyes of mine, Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me somewise.
column350: The day of departure You came full of grieving And to see I was leaving The tears 'gan to start sure With the heavy torture Of sorrows unbrightened When you lie down at night and When there to you dreams rise, Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me somewise.
column351: Deep is my assurance Of you, little green eyes, That in truth you realise Something of my durance Eyes of hope's fair assurance And good premonition By virtue of whose condition All green colours I prize.
column352: Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me somewise.
column353: Would God I might know you To which quarter bended And why comprehended When sighings overflow you, And if you must go through Some certain despair, For that you lose his care Who was faithful always.
column354: Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me these days.
column355: Through never a moment I've known how to live lest All my thoughts but as one pressed You-ward for their concernment.
column356: May God send chastisement If in this I belie me And if it truth be My own little green eyes.
column357: Ah, Heaven be willing That you think of me somewise.
column358: III Poplars of the meadow, Fountains of Madrid, Now I am absent from you All are slandering me.
column359: Each of you is telling How evil my chance is The wind among the branches, The fountains in their welling To every one telling You were happy to see.
column360: Now I am absent from you All are slandering me.
column361: With good right I may wonder For that at my last leaving The plants with sighs heaving And the waters in tears were.
column362: That you played double, never Thought I this could be, Now I am absent from you All are slandering me.
column363: There full in your presence Music you sought to waken, Later I'm forsaken Since you are ware of my absence.
column364: God, wilt Thou give me patience Here while suffer I ye, Now I am absent from you All are slandering me.
column365: IV The day draweth nearer, And morrow ends our meeting, Ere they take thee sleeping Be up--away, my treasure!
column366: Soft, leave her breasts all unheeded, Far hence though the master still remaineth!
column367: For soon uptil our earth regaineth The sun all embraces dividing.
column368: N'er grew pleasure all unimpeded, N'er was delight lest passion won, And to the wise man the fit occasion Has not yet refused a full measure: Be up--away, my treasure!
column369: If that my love thy bosom inflameth With honest purpose and just intention, To free me from my soul's contention Give over joys the day shameth; Who thee lameth he also me lameth, And my good grace builds all in thy good grace; Be up--away!
column370: Fear leaveth place, That thou art here, no more unto pleasure, Be up--away, my treasure!
column371: Although thou with a sleep art wresting, 'Tis rightful thou bringst it close, That of the favour one meeting shows An hundred may hence be attesting.
column372: 'Tis fitting too thou shouldst be mindful That the ease which we lose now, in kind, full Many a promise holds for our leisure; Ere they take thee sleeping; Be up--away, my treasure!
column373: Hic Jacet The coroner's merry little children   Have such twinkling brown eyes.
column374: Their father is not of gay men   And their mother jocular in no wise, Yet the coroner's merry little children         Laugh so easily.
column376: Fruit for them is upon all branches.
column378: how they jibe at loss, for   Kind heaven fills their little paunches!
column379: It's the coroner's merry, merry children         Who laugh so easily.
column380: Contemporania The corner of a great rain Steamy with the country Has fallen upon my garden.
column381: I go back and forth now And the little leaves follow me Talking of the great rain, Of branches broken, And the farmer's curses!
column382: But I go back and forth In this corner of a garden And the green shoots follow me Praising the great rain.
column383: We are not curst together, The leaves and I, Framing devices, flower devices And other ways of peopling The barren country.
column384: Truly it was a very great rain That makes the little leaves follow me.
column385: To wish Myself Courage On the day when youth is no more upon me I will write of the leaves and the moon in a tree top!
column386: I will sing then the song, long in the making-- When the stress of youth is put away from me.
column387: How can I ever be written out as men say?
column388: Surely it is merely an interference with the long song-- This that I am now doing.
column389: But when the spring of it is worn like the old moon And the eaten leaves are lace upon the cold earth-- Then I will rise up in my great desire-- Long at the birth--and sing me the youth-song!
